column1: Will the location of the administrative services building in Bakhmut, Ukraine, cease to be under Ukrainian control before 26 January 2023, according to the Institute for the Study of War?
column6: ['Society', 'Security and Conflict']
Clearly not.
High chance that Bakhmut will fall before the end of February, but not quite yet
#BravoZulu
14 hours left.

I do not think Bakhmut has any strategic value. Ukrainian military command have reasons to think it does have strategic value. In the mean time the time frame of this forecast is closing, so I am taking the side of Ukraine.
"US officials advised Ukraine to hold off on launching a major offensive against Russian forces until the latest supply of US weaponry is in place and training has been provided."
Lot's of ground to cover in 3 days.
Take it with a grain of salt, perhaps, but a very similar question is at 20% on Metaculus right now. Granted, it's part of the "Beginners' Tournament".
Bumping up a few points, cheap insurance.
Russia apparently only 3-4km from main supply route. AFU may have to retreat very soon, its going to be close but 4days isn't enough
Impossible at this stage.
Stick a fork in it it’s done
Decided that was too big a swing
Apparently the us have advised a tactile retreat from bahkmut, only recently mourns though https://twitter.com/sentdefender/status/1616562438299869184?s=46&t=V1jYJUnvex2up7_gFFtJKA
My prior knowledge of this topic is very limited. From what I can gather:
I have underestimated the persistence and determination of UA soldiers and not properly weighted how much urban warfare advantages local defenders.
May be, Ukraine can temporarily sacrifice Bakhmut as tactical withdrawal, not a big deal.
With only a week to go, and Ukrainian defenses holding solid both north and south, I can't see any possibility now for Russia to take Bakhmut within the timescale.
Militaryland.net shows the same
Not enough time to do it at this point.
Dropping to two percent. 10 days left.
If any are interested, this is one of my resources for UA/RU. This is just one of my assistive visual tools
All in
https://www.rferl.org/a/inside-ukraines-artyomsalt-salt-mine/29993212.html
It appears that RU efforts have shifted focus to Soledar and environs, while UA remains determined to hold Bakhmut.
No sign of continuing movements beyond Soledar. There would have to be significant progress within the next few days
Only 11 days left.
Curious about the extension of red going north west from Kurdiumivka towards Chasiv Yar on this map https://liveuamap.com/

Not a typical update, but info is info? Ukrainian fighters in Bakhmut have just/very recently received a humanitarian package from Canada collected by friends of a friend: warm socks, hand warmers, small things like that. The fact that they receive mail—and are able to send back thank you messages and photos—tells me Bakhmut still stands and there’re no signs of retreat (yet?) on the ground.

ISW: "Russian forces likely captured Soledar after committing significant resources to a highly attritional tactical victory which will accelerate degraded Russian forces’ likely culmination near Bakhmut.[9] Russian forces may decide to maintain a consistently high pace of assaults in the Bakhmut area, but Russian forces’ degraded combat power and cumulative exhaustion will prevent these assaults from producing operationally significant results"https://understandingwar.org/backgrounder/russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-january-12-2023
Reasons why UA may be able to hang on

Two weeks, while they are still stuck at Soledar. The Ukrainians have massed a bulk of their armoured & mechanized forces in the east. A waterway splits the city in two, and the attacker would have to crawl, through the city already reduced to rubble which gives the defender some noticeable advantage, all the way to the western riverbank. They´ve been "on the gates" for months now. I´d be inclined to say that they cant make it so fast, unless the ukrainians finally decide to give up the city (Why?).

https://understandingwar.org/backgrounder/russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-january-11-2023"Russian forces have not yet fully captured Soledar despite recent Russian advances, and the possible capture of Soledar is unlikely to enable Russian forces to capture Bakhmut. ISW assesses that Russian forces have not yet captured Soledar, despite numerous claims from Russian sources.[17] Russian claims about Russian advances in Soledar continue to generate discussion amongst Russian sources about the likelihood of Russian forces capturing Bakhmut.[18] Some Russian sources have begun discussing an implausible collapse of the current Ukrainian frontline and a Ukrainian retreat as far back as Slovyansk and Kramatorsk.[19] The Russian discussion about the imminent capture of Bakhmut and the collapse of Ukrainian defensive lines are divorced from the current operational reality in the Bakhmut area, where Russian forces remain far from severing Ukrainian ground lines of communication (GLOCs) needed to encircle Bakhmut.[20] Russian offensive operations to capture Bakhmut have likely culminated due to degraded operational capabilities.[21]"
Had a wobble but time is Ticking down too fast I think.
The timeline is very short. Lowering because:
Soledar mostly taken, Bakhmut next with only 2 weeks remaining...

Balancing the short period left against the recent advances around Soledar. If I believed all the claimed Russian control (yellow) on the ISW map was genuine, then I would be going quite a lot higher, Krasna Hora and Berkhivka would be especially important.

Russian forces are escalating their onslaught against Ukrainian positions around the wrecked eastern city of Bakhmut, Ukrainian officials said, bringing new levels of death and devastation in the grinding, months-long battle.

+2% for a Russian push into Soledar, north of Bakhmut, which could cut important Ukainian lines of supply (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-64219979). Waiting to see if this is a localized attack or if Russians will launch another offensive to the south to try and surround the city. Even if this happens, though, holding Bakhmut has become a significant objective for the Ukrainians and they could bring in mobile reserves for a counterattack. Also, Mariupol held out for a significant amount of time after surrounded by Russian troops, so I think the Russians still have a hard fight ahead of them if they want to capture the city. So, I think this is still not realistic at least for the timeline of this question.
I don't see the conditions on the ground to forecast a change of control in the immediate term
Soledar is semi surrounded and likely to fall to the Russians very soon. [Thanks to @Chrisp for the informative youtube link.]
Dropping the percentage, 16 days left.

The Ukrainians have supposedly withdrawn from Soledar, but I think Russian advances in the north (which appear to be substantial) will not force the Ukrainians to abandon Bakhmut in the time allotted.
Winter war is cold a s slow.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Suz3jeBQHoI
Situation in soledar deteriorating for the AFU. Still think time is on the side of no however. Rumours circulating of AFU retreat from soledar now, so may have called it wrong
Increasing the probability a little due to Russian advances around Soledar.
AFU reenforced at soledar. Should be enough to slow any advance in a until after the 26th
Isw indicating Wagner making progress in surrounding settlements, but probably not enough time in this question

The problem the Russians have is that if they break the Ukrainian defensive line - which they appear to have done in the south and may be close to doing in the center - they just wind up in built-up areas where they will have to contest each block, and maybe each building. The Russians have clearly made some progress north and south of the city, but as of now, nowhere near what they need to encircle it, or even threaten it with encirclement. And there are only 19 days left until the question closes.

If it continues at its current pace, not gonna happen by our date. But is there guarantee that the pace won’t change? Encirclement is a concern. Temporary retreat to avoid encirclement is a concern. The Mariupol scenario is a concern. There’s plenty of motivation on both sides. Lots of competing claims from both sides as well, and we can’t know what’s real and what’s propaganda until after the fact—probably even until after the war. I seem to be more uncertain than most here that the pace of the Russian advance won’t change suddenly, and re the ability of Ukrainian forces to defend Bakhmut. [A note of caution: I also have a history of average (recently) to disastrous (2014) forecasts on Russian military and Putin’s decision making.]
coming back down due to counter offensives by AFU overnight and the ticking clock to the end of Jan. I think I overreacted to the soledar news yesterday in retrospect
May be, Ukraine can temporarily sacrifice Bakhmut as tactical withdrawal, not a big deal
Reducing for time passed.
Actually the more I read about soledar the more it seems RuAF are having some sucess so would be remiss not bump a little more I think(edited due to terrible phone keypad typos)
Coming up a little. Reports of the VDV outside soledar, moving up as shows RuAF are taking this strategic area seriously.

Putin’s call for a Christmas “ceasefire”—36 hours or all the way until Epiphany, 19 January—is mainly for domestic consumption. As Prigozhin said in the video, “There are no holidays in war.” (He did use the w-word.)
21 days left

Passage of time. There's only a few weeks left, the Russians are still a mile away, and a mile can be a long distance in urban warfare against a dug-in, determined defender -- especially in the dead of winter (see the 10-day forecast). There is even a river, the Bakhmutovka River, that the Russians still need to cross. Ukraine's President Zelenskyy handed over a battle flag from Bakhmut to US Congress members, so there's no way they won't keep defending every square inch.
Fresh NYT article: More than 60 percent of Bakhmut has been destroyed, a Ukrainian official says.
re: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1574184 @lbiii

Others have already quoted Prigozhin here with his “500 lines of defense” explanation. He sounded genuinely pissed with analysts (whom he called “clowns”) trying to put a timeline on Bakhmut capture. What stood out for me is that the Russians have been at it since the summer.
Hedging a little.
Some Ukrainian officers say resistance has forced Russia to temper its assault on Bakhmut and shift resources to surrounding areas
"‘Every house a fortress’: Wagner leader counts cost as Russia stalls in Bakhmut
Prigozhin’s latest comments sure don’t instill any confidence re: this resolving yes. But could just be more noise. Regardless, lowering a bit.

I am of the opinion that the Russia army conscripts are marching bravely into their battles - as men who were civilians just weeks before, and then disappearing on their commanders and a result of that is Russian commanders are concentrating their forces in order to keep them accounted for and available for battle. THAT in turn presents large troop concentrations that are easy targets for HIMAR units.
Dropping to 1/20 since there's still a lot of noise, but it sounds like the Russian forces have run out of steam, and instead, the Ukrainians claim to be counterattacking.

"Whatever Putin might say, the slow to minimal progress in Bakhmut is one of a number of indications that Russia lacks offensive combat power. In a Ukrainian TV interview highlighted by the Institute for the Study of War, Budanov said Russia had gone from firing 60,000 shells a day (the top of the range suggested by Ukraine’s most senior military commander in August) to “19,000 to 20,000”, explaining why Russia has been so keen to seek arms from Iran and North Korea.Much of Moscow’s military effort has gone into a cruel and relentless bombardment of Ukraine’s energy infrastructure, leading to longer and longer blackouts across key cities. But there are very tentative signs here too that Russia is faltering: it fired about 20 cruise missiles at Ukraine on New Year’s Eve – serious of course, but nothing like the 80 to 100 it unleashed on days in October and November, although only a few days earlier in December, 69 missiles were fired at Ukrainian targets."

Putting a very low probability given the short timeline of the question, the lack of Russian artillery ammunition, the difficulty of urban warfare for an attacking army, and the relative ease with which Ukraine can reinforce from Kherson (relative to the Russians who have longer supply lines). Bakhmut is politically important to Putin because of his promises to retake Donbas, however, the rate of advance seems very slow currently even with Russian reinforcements from Kherson. Good analysis by Michael Kofman on War on the Rocks: https://warontherocks.com/2022/12/localized-offensives-the-direction-of-the-conflict/.
Holding for now, but the Russians appear to ave achieved a small breach in the Ukrainian defensive line in the southeast.
https://www.eurasiareview.com/01012023-russian-mercenary-leaders-war-of-words-with-moscows-military-brass-deepens-amid-fighting-in-bakhmut/
@lbiii posted a useful source below, as did @zwoods. (https://militaryland.net/news/invasion-day-310-summary/) The Russian advance is slow but ongoing.

I've primarily been following the MilitaryLand maps, which went without updating for 8 days around Christmas. New update as of today. You can use back/forward key commands to see the from/to, which is a nice way to understand the shifting battlefield.

Looking at the latest ISW report and the interactive map. Lots of Russian claims. The below and the text in the map (at the below link, it cannot be cut&pasted because it's a picture and I don't want to retype it) indicating there may be fighting inside the city itself causes me to raise.

News out of Ukraine suggest that “Bakhmut as a city no longer exists”—so extensive is its destruction. The Russians are reportedly very motivated to capture it as a key point in the east. Which should make the Ukrainians very motivated to defend it. Low probability due to so little time left, and we’d probably see “Claimed Russian Control” first.
ISW reported the following on Dec 28.
Down a point. The possibility exists, but only very remotely at this moment.

As pointed out by @Anneinak below, the map has changed significantly. Russian forced have advanced along broad fronts both north and south of Bakhmut. They are now within one mile of the administrative services building. More importantly, they appear to be half way towards the objective of encircling the city.
I read about this front in the war every day. I find it hard to figure out what is really happening because there's so much spin.

Reducing for passage of time. No significant advances by Russia since last forecast and latest reports seem to suggest the pace of fighting has slowed. It now seems almost certain that Bakhmut will hold another month unless something significant changes on the ground.
Russia`s gains toward Bakhmut
Thanks @Zbigniew-Sobkiewicz & @cosaib for your cogent input!

The battle for Stalingrad looms large in Soviet/Russian history. The Soviets defeated the German Army after operation Uranus, during which they encircled the Germans. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operation_Uranus Also, the Russians captured Mariupol in May after a nearly three month siege. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Mariupol Bakhmut doesn't have the tunnel system like the Azovstal Iron and Steel Works, so it could not withstand a long siege.

Russian progress in the Bakhmut region has been minimal since the summer. As of this writing, there is no chance of a Russian encirclement of the city, and the continued frontal attacks have been costly without being fruitful. I don’t think Bakhmut will fall to the Russians any time soon.
Russians losing ground up and down the line. Without reinforcement I think they are really unlikely to have success in the time window of this question
Russia's gains in the region around Bakhmut have been minimal; I doubt Russia will make any serious gains by the deadline of this question.
I see that a 2nd bridge across the river has now been blown up: that will make it much harder for RU to get to the city center.

I think about this Bakhmut question all the time. I see RU making progress, but so far it has been slow, and if it continues at this pace Bakhmut will not fall to RU this winter UNLESS there is some sort of UA collapse. . . . Which could happen: who anticipated the RU withdrawal from Kherson more than a month in advance? But I agree with @sevedb, this is UA HOMELAND and it will not give an inch easily, even if that inch has become an unrecognizable pile of rubble. . . .as I type I'm talking myself into lowering my forecast for it to fall. LOL!

Back up a bit after seeing aerial footage on CNN of Bakhmut. Lots of smoke and explosions. But with Zelenskyy's visit to USA, it may boost the morale of the Ukrainian soldiers. In contrast to @Anneinak's view here:
I see Zelenski's visit in a negative way. I see it as an effort to boost sagging morale and urge soldiers to "hold the fort".
Dropping back down to nearly 0 after lull and indication RU Mil simply does not have enthusiasm to make it happen. There is more enthusiasm for long range and infrastructure attack.
Moving a little down. If zelensky is pitching up Ukraine aren’t about to give it up anytime me soon

I'll stay below the crowd. If Russian forces are able to advance north and south of Bakhmut, threatening encirclement, I'll flip. The map doesn't show that, and I tend to believe the Russians won't be able to advance significantly on any axis.

The Russians appear to have made some progress in the north, but on the three maps that I look at aside from ISW, none appear to show Russian advances in the south. On the MilitaryLand map (in my opinion the most useful), you can see multiple Ukrainain strong points South of Bakhmut and north of Toretsk. The map also indicates that two mechanized infantry brigades and one mechanized infantry battalion are in that area, as well as three infantry formations. So I don't think Bakhmut is in danger of being encircled any time soon.

Lowering slightly on passage of time, but noting that RU has made slight progress over the last three days, in Bakhmut as well as Soledar to north. They have also, within last 48 hours, taken the town of Yakovlivka, approximately 15km to the NE. To the south, no clear territorial gains, but there appears to be a significant push at Klischiivka and the immediate area to the south. That, along with the taking of Yakovlivka looks like a push to encircle Bakhmut. Really just the same story as the past many weeks, but I'm watching RU progress to the north and south of Bakhmut with more interest than I have been previously.

The Ukrainians have shown themselves to be very resourceful. They are receiving Western aid that is published in the news, plus a lot more help that is classified. The war is existential for both sides. The kind of world our grandchildren will live in will be greatly affected by the outcome, as will the kind of country Russia will be. So the collective West has every incentive to provide the maximum aid possible. Between Western aid and Ukrainian determination I will bet that ultimately the Ukrainians will prevail.
Time

I see a scenario where this Battle Field is used to keep Ukraine from repositioning to protect Kyiv from a northern encirclement - OR the opposite. One battlefield will pivot action on the other. Logistics and Winter may dictate which battle is the main thrust.

Russian operations in Bakhmut may seem senseless, but Bakhmut isn't called "the key to Donetsk" for nothing. The Russians know the possibilities that controlling the city opens, and Ukraine understands the challenges losing it will bring.
Lots of interesting thoughts being raised. So here are my views on one of the big questions.
Think my last update was too much of a swing
@Zbigniew-Sobkiewicz
Why is Russia putting in so many resources to capture a small city that “would have limited operational value”?
I found excelent article: https://defence24.pl/wojna-na-ukrainie-raport-specjalny-defence24/bachmut-perspektywa-dalszej-obrony-miasta-analiza

@Anneinak has pointed out that Melitopol may be the next target of the UAF, and that a withdrawal from Bakhmut could happen soon. See https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1563867. @Anneinak's thesis, if I understand correctly, is that the Russians are throwing so many forces into Bakhmut that it is only a matter of time, and with 43 days left she gives it a 75% probability. She points out that UAF could compensate for a loss of minor importance at Bakhmut by making a very strategic gain towards Melitopol.
Northern Donbas
Maybe this is just wishful thinking (not good for making predictions), but I'll tilt slightly towards Ukraine holding on.
Russian forces are attacking Bakhmut on three sides, and have made some advances to the northeast of the city. See link in @zwoods post below. I'll change to a 50/50 chance.
This link has detailed maps of the Ukraine (including the area around Bakhmut):
Bumping this up significantly since Zelenskyy was just interviewed saying most of the city is destroyed, the kind of thing he’s said before having to surrender a city to the Russians.

Bakhmut is a hellscape. Military people have said it does not have much strategic value to the Ukrainians, so why have they stubbornly held it in the face of constant Russian attacks? Some perspective is provided by this Financial Times article. https://on.ft.com/3Ydr692.
Adjusting from 0 to 30 due to latest entrenchment by Wagner/RU in two positions. More Tactical than strategic, but the entrenchment is much more than prior capability
Current situation east of bahkmut
https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-december-7
https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-december-7

From CNBC: https://www.cnbc.com/2022/12/07/live-updates-latest-news-on-russia-and-war-in-ukraine.htmlPro-Russian official claims conditions are ripe for the capturing of BakhmutPro-Russian official Denis Pushilin, the acting head of the separatist “Donetsk People’s Republic” in eastern Ukraine, has claimed that Russian forces in the region — arguably the most hotly-contested region in the Ukraine war at the moment — could soon be in a position to advance and capture Bakhmut.Denis Pushilin (C), leader of the separatists in the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DNR) arrives to deliver a press conference in Donetsk, on April 11, 2022.Denis Pushilin (C), leader of the separatists in the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic (DNR) arrives to deliver a press conference in Donetsk, on April 11, 2022.Alexander Nemenov | AFP | Getty ImagesPushilin told the TASS news agency that the “liberation” of Mayorsk near Horlivka, just to the south of Bakhmut, “created the prerequisites for advancing to Dzerzhinsk [known as ‘Toretsk’ in Ukrainian] and the subsequent encirclement of Artemovsk” — the Russian name for Bakhmut.He said units of the Russian state-sanctioned private military company, the Wagner Group, were working “in Bakhmut” and were seeing “certain successes,” echoing comments by Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu who said on Tuesday that a number of settlements near Bakhmut had come under the control of the Russian armed forces.Fighting in Donetsk has descended into bloody trench warfare in recent months with fierce battles over every mile of territory and settlement surrounding Bakhmut.Russia is believed to see the city as a key target, believing that capturing it will enable it to sever Ukrainian supply lines and allow its forces to advance toward Sloviansk and Kramatorsk to the north of Bakhmut.CNBC was unable to verify Pushilin’s claims. The General Staff of Ukraine’s armed forces said Wednesday morning that Russian forces continued to focus their efforts on “conducting offensive operations” in the area around Bakhmut.It’s not the first time that Pushilin has claimed that Bakhmut is close to encirclement, having said the same thing last week. Ukraine vehemently denies it is even close to being semi-encircled, with one official telling CNBC that Russia is seeing masses of personnel losses in the area, and little gains, although the official admitted the fighting was intense.— Holly Ellyatt

Interesting sometimes to hear what the other side are saying. Russian media (yes, I know its biased but so is all the rest) now reports that Ukraine is sending reinforcements to Bakhmut (Russian name Artyomovsk) but also struggling with supply issues and suffering heavy casualties. Of course, Ukrainian and Western media says the same about Russian forces, so hard to know who really has the upper hand, or whether both sides are struggling.
Lowering for passage of time and seeming lack of progress. Still quite bullish vs. crowd.

Phillips Payson O'Brien is an American historian and professor of strategic studies at the University of St Andrews. He is the author of "How the War Was Won: Air-Sea Power and Allied Victory in World War II" and other books. https://www.amazon.com/How-War-Was-Won-Cambridge/dp/110871689X/ref=sr_1_1
Additional Russian gains in the area yesterday
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/dec/05/ukraine-war-winter-phase-russian-troops
Russians continue to make incremental progress attacking the city. It looks to me like the front edge of Russian control is under 2 miles from the administrative services building.

The Ukrainians have carefully constructed and controlled the narrative since the beginning of the conflict. So this Ukrainian source, https://odessa-journal.com/the-professional-backbone-of-the-russian-forces-in-the-avdiivka-and-bakhmut-directions-was-eliminated/, may or may not be reliable. But if it's true the Russians are having a very tough time taking Bakhmut. I'll lower the odds to 25%.

There is a lot of information online regarding the Ukraine War -- strategy, weapons, logistics, tactics, etc -- and quite a lot specifically regarding the Bakhmut situation. [See postings by @zwoods and others.] If you haven't been following the Bakhmut situation very closely (and there are people who do that for a living) here is an overview article.

Now that the period od winter warfare has set in - Russians know that soldiers in trench's face hypothermia and have to expend more effort on creature comforts to stay alive - it concentrates targets into tight areas. Now a strategy begins to exhaust Ukraine war stocks, crush the infrastructure and start a 6 million strong wave of refugees into western Europe.
The war is only going one way now, and that’s in an Easterly direction.
15% - base, based on the fact that this battle has been going for 125 days with very few gains from russia, projecting this forward for further 53 days until the end of this question
Time
This is why I am at 50/50
https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-december-2

Well, I've got to increase the odds on this if Russia is making a concerted effort to take it.https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-likely-planning-encircle-donetsk-oblast-town-bakhmut-britain-says-2022-12-03/
Lowering slightly for passage of time, but still staying quite high to correct for having been, IMO, way too low for a period. Actual belief something like 60%.
For people relying on ISW reports for unbiased discussion of the state of the war, you may want to read this: https://responsiblestatecraft.org/2022/06/12/a-case-study-in-american-propaganda/
Geolocated footage posted on December 1 shows Ukrainian forces reportedly withdrawing from positions on the western side of the highway that runs through Opytne (within 4km south of Bakhmut).

I have been reading about this front in the battle since this question was launched. My bias is pro-UA but I have read so much about the ambition and determination of the leadership of the Russian soldiers in the Wagner Group, who have made this their target, that I am afraid that poor Bakhmut will not be able to withstand their onslaught.

Russia appears to have taken Kurdiumivka and moving in on Bakhmut from the south. This is unlikely to lead to immediate victory but if they are able to take the high ground, they could gain fire control over one of the two major roads into Bakhmut, impacting the ability of Ukraine to resupply their front line.
Seems to be a (the?) primary Russian target at the moment, and they have two months to pull it off.
From the picture embedded in the below report:
Rumors of additional Russian gains south of the city

Not easy to see due to different levels of detail in the maps, but in the past four months RU has steadily gained ground around bakhmut, especially to the south. Media reports about them not making progress are not accurate, although the cost has been enormous for them.
RU continues chipping away at the edges

Reducing a bit even tho RU has crossed the highway south of Opytne. RU use of thermite ordnance is perhaps a sign of weakness but may put more pressure on defenders. not completely clear whether they’re using it in bakhmut or further north
Time

Russia is having a terrible war. Momentum is with Ukraine. Russia will not gain any more territory. The question is how much territory the will manage to keep. If they haven’t already got Bakhmut now, they will never get it.
Depends on the weather
It takes weeks for the Russians capturing even tiny villages and Bakhmut is a small town. With winter approaching that doesn't make easier for poorly equiped demoralised attackers.
Was probably crediting RU too much for the stalemate in the sense that UA is not trying to advance in this area Holding the line is success under that assumption, and the best they can really do
RU took a smidgeon of Bakhmut today

Urban warfare against a determined defender always difficult. As the article https://www.coffeeordie.com/lessons-winter-warfare outlines, the winter in Ukraine can be particularly brutal, which should tend to slow things down. That said, intense winter urban battles have happened in the past, resulting in significant change in territory, for example https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Debaltseve
RU still unable to make progress although they started withdrawing troops from Kherson weeks ago. Roughly 70 days remaining

The Donetsk/Luhansk front have been the most fortified and least successful front for both sides. With recent Russian combat losses of men and equipment it is doubtful they will be able to retake much territory near Donetsk.

Continued RU assaults, with some modest success. High likelihood that this objective is more important to RU than UA. Although RU gains have been extraordinarily slow, no fight this intense can objectively be rated a sure thing.

Bakhmut is heavily defended and Russia has failed to make progress in recent weeks. Attempts at encirclement have proved challenging. The engagement line to the north has been stable for some time and the Ukrainian advance in Kharkiv and Liman will make progress here even more difficult. Russian forces have made some progress to the South, and success in capturing Kurdiumivka could present opportunities. But even if that is achieved, the proximity of Chasiv Yar to the West would make a full encirclement of Bakhmut seem highly improbable. Without such an encirclement it comes down to a full frontal assault, and Russia seems too stretched and too risk adverse to commit the forces required to achieve success in this way. A sufficiently deep winter freeze may nullify some of the terrain advantages of the defender, but only if Russian forces are able to prepare their forces with the right equipment in time, and it would still be a highly costly urban assault.

the building does exist anymore it was destroyed three and a half weeks ago don’t believe the news Ukraine has been completely destroyed Turkey now really knows they made a wrong decision making a secret deal with the wrong group

ISW report today outlines likely moves on both sides pasted below. Unclear how much of this will come to pass. Note that the language used displays the author’s disdain for Ru capabilities, which I want to believe, but think it might be unwise:

Still conflicting stories about the status of Opytne, with some sources saying it was the other Opytne (about an hour from Bakhmut by car) that fell, rather than the one that is an hour from Bakhmut on foot.

Opytne and Ivanhrad apparently at least in part in RU hands today according to numerous unofficial sources. Last month RU gained a foothold in both before being driven out by a counterattack. Opytne center is 4.7 km from the admin building in Bakhmut.

Bakhmut is basically on the front line, and has been for a while. ISW shows some Russian advances in the area, but equally Ukrainian ones too. There are two months on this question and it states “ceases to have control” not that Ukraine doesn’t have control in Jan. So the Russians could have control for 1hr for this question to complete yes. So what are the scenarios?

Bakhmut is unimportant strategically but has outsized importance in RU politics. RU has been making slow progress, the trajectory of which may change with the end of fighting in Kherson. I suspect UA will continue to defend hard but perhaps not at the expense of preparing for attacks on the more important regions to the north or south.

Russian troops (mostly DNR and LNR troops and Wagner Group mercenaries) have been fighting for Bakhmut for about six months, and the lines have barely moved. I suppose if the Russians were able to get a large amount of hardware out of Kherson, are able to transfer it hundreds of kilometers during the winter, and decide they have no better place to use it, some of it might wind up on the Bakhmut front and make a difference. I just don't see any of that actually happening.
